story: In the past, the former actress has admitted using semi-permeant straightening treatments for her hair.Speaking in 2011, she said: &ldquoMy mum is black and my dad is Dutch and Irish, so the texture of my hair is densely curly.&ldquoI&rsquove been getting Brazilian blowouts for a couple of years.However, according to Myka Meier, who runs the Plaza Hotel's Duchess Effect etiquette courses, these beauty treatments could provide a very public indiction when she may be expecting.Ms Meier told the Sun&rsquos Fabulous magazine the chemicals involved in these treatments mean they might have to be avoided in pregnancy.                Meghan will 'NOT' talk to father until he contacts in &lsquoRESPECTFUL' way                Meghan and Kate wear THIS secret item to stop their dresses 'FLYING...She said of the Duchess: &ldquoThe one thing that might be interesting is her hair.&ldquoWe don&rsquot know what she does now, but it is likely she uses a keratin or a Brazilian treatment to straighten it.&ldquoAs soon as she gets pregnant she will no longer be able to use those same products which could be very interesting.&ldquoI use the same products and have very curly, frizzy hair and when I got pregnant I had to stop using all of those.Instead, the expert thinks Meghan may wear her hair up, rather than long and loose as we are accustomed to seeing.Ms Meier continued: &ldquoI think we&rsquoll see her wearing more of a bun when that happens, which could be a tell tale sign she is pregnant as she&rsquoll no longer be able to use those stringent chemicals that are often used or that beautiful glossy look.Meghan Markle's hair could change if she falls pregnant (Image:  )The best pictures of Meghan Markle as she celebrates her 37th birthday.                    PA1 of 45The best pictures of the Duchess of Sussex as celebrates her 37th birthdayHowever, the etiquette coach thinks we may have to wait a little longer than we&rsquore used to to find out about any Royal baby from the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.She said: &ldquoWith the Duchess of Cambridge, she was forced to tell everyone she was expecting because of hospitalisations.&ldquoHowever, with the Duchess of Sussex, hopefully that is not the case and she doesn&rsquot suffer with any sickness and she might try to hide her pregnancy a little longer and give herself privacy.&ldquoShe&rsquos already known to wear loose clothing so I think it&rsquos not like she&rsquoll go from tight clothing to very loose.One doctor agreed with Ms Meier&rsquos predictions, and suggested keratin hair treatments are avoided in pregnancy.Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patient.info, said: &ldquoLots of mums worry whether beauty treatments as well as medicines are safe when they&rsquore pregnant.&ldquoHair treatments obviously aren&rsquot taken internally like tablets but small amounts can be absorbed through the scalp and if there are fumes you can breathe them in.&ldquoThere isn&rsquot enough research to say for certain whether keratin treatments are safe, so doctors will usually suggest to be careful.She explained there is one ingredient which could be particularly dangerous: &ldquoThe exception is keratin treatments containing formaldehyde - and there have been concerns that at high levels, this can cause birth defects.&ldquoSo I recommend that women absolutely avoid any keratin product which might contain formaldehyde.Chemical hair straightening treatments last around four months each time, and can cost anything between &pound100 and &pound350.

title: atmosphere mesosphere cloud formation space weather forecast
story: Researchers were baffled by the late blood of noctilucent clouds (Image: SPACE WEATHER)Scientists have been scratching their heads over late blossoming cloud formations which were seen in the mesosphere &ndash the region in the Earth&rsquos atmosphere between 50 and 80 kilometres above the surface, almost touching space.The strange thing is not that there has been noctilucent clouds (NLCs) &ndash clouds formed when summertime water vapour rises to the edge of space and forms long streaks of ice crystals in the sky &ndash but that they are appearing so late in the year.NLCs typically form in May, become intense in June before fading in July.However, this year, they have reached their peak in late July, heading into August, and exploding &ldquowith unusual luminosity.                UK long term weather: Rains here but cold snap could last 11 YEARS                Massive man-made star will be visible in night sky from EarthWebsite Space Weather says that reports of NLCs in August have tripled in comparison to the same time last year.But researchers have stated that this is due to an unexpected surge of water vapour in the mesosphere.Lynn Harvey of Colorado's Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics (LASP) said: There has been an unexpected surge of water vapour in the mesosphere.July went out like a lion!The clouds form in the mesosphere (Image: Randy Russell, UCAR)Still, it remains unclear why there is so much water vapour so late in the year.One theory is to do with the upcoming solar minimum.The sun follows cycles of roughly 11 years where it reaches a solar maximum and then a solar minimum.During a solar maximum, the sun gives off more heat and is littered with sunspots. Less heat in a solar minimum is due to a decrease in magnetic waves.The sun was not expected to head into a solar minimum until around 2020, but it appears to be heading in earlySpace Weather says: &ldquoThe phenomenon could be linked to solar minimum, now underway. It is notable that the coldest and wettest years in the mesosphere prior to 2018 were 2008-2009&ndashthe previous minimum of the 11-year solar cycle.&ldquoAnother possibility involves planetary wave activity in the southern hemisphere which can, ironically, boost the upwelling of water vapour tens of thousands of miles away in the north.

story: Anti-Brexit campaigner Femi Oluwole suggested 1.4 million British citizens living abroad would lose the right to stay in the European Union without a deal.Mr Oluwole suggested that failing to secure an agreement with the bloc would strip expats of their right to live in any EU member state.But talkRADIO&nbsphost Julia Hartley-Brewer called him out, saying: No, it doesn&rsquot. That&rsquos a load of nonsense.Why on Earth would that happen? I bet my house on it.                Hunt tells EU countries not to follow UK who face 'difficult period'                RBS could move BILLIONS abroad over hard Brexit fears despite TAXPA...Ms Hartley-Brewer, who also said she would be perfectly happy with a no deal, was backed by the Institute of Economic Affairs boss Mark Littlewood.Mr Littlewood listened to Mr Oluwole's claims, visibly shaking his head, before adding: We are not going to have 1.4 million people evacuated.The anti-Brexit campaigner hit back saying that both Brexiteers were in a very privileged condition to have no fear about a no deal Brexit.Mr Oluwole said: It&rsquos a very, very privileged condition being able to say that no deal is acceptable.Brexit news: Hartley-Brewer branded as nonsensical Oluwele's claims about Brexit (Image: TALKRADIO)No deal means the 1.4 million British people who are living on the other side of the Channel would have no right to live in their own home.He also suggested people arguing against a second Brexit referendum are to be considered undemocratic, insisting British voters should have a say on the final deal agreed on with Brussels.Mr Oluwele continued: One could just as strongly argue that the democratic thing to do is for people to have a say.One of the major arguments behind Brexit in the first place was &lsquowe never signed up to this.&rsquo &lsquoWe never signed up to this, we signed up to a simple trade agreement in 1974 and it became something different.&rsquoRight now we have an opportunity that to have a say on what our new relationship with the EU is going to be. I think it&rsquos undemocratic to argue we shouldn&rsquot get one.Tory frontbencher Alistair Burt, who backed Remain at the EU referendum, launched a survey on his constituency website seeking local views on the possibility of a re-run of the historic vote.Mr Burt said he wanted to gauge opinion in his North East Bedfordshire constituency after a number of residents had voiced anger and concern about the progress with the country's withdrawal from the bloc.But Eurosceptic Tory MPs accused him of breaching government policy given Theresa May's repeated rejection of demands for a second EU referendum.Tory MP and Leave campaigner Andrew Bridgen said: Alistair Burt is an arch-Europhile. I hope this is not an indication of the way Government policy is heading.We haven't yet implemented the will of the people from the first referendum.I am not finding anyone in North West Leicestershire asking me for a second referendum.

title: man woman couple perfect match kidney pancreas transplant operation
story: Steven Jarvis and Michelle Commons fell for each other while awaiting double transplants   (Image: SWNS)The pair, from Basildon, Essex, grew close and romance blossomed as they received dialysis treatment.In early May, Michelle received a call saying a suitable match had been found and she underwent a successful kidney transplant.Only a week after Michelle was discharged from Basildon University Hospital, Steven received his own life-changing call.And after the success of his operation the loved-up couple are now sharing a home.                Transplant survivor reveals her moving story and appeals for donations                Toddler, 3, diagnosed with kidney failure after heart transplantAccount manager Michelle said: &ldquoAt first we started as friends and found we had so much in common due to our similar experiences. We had our first date in December and just clicked.She said of her transplant: &ldquoSteven was there every day I was in hospital. Seeing me go through it gave him insight into what having a transplant was like.&ldquoThe staff on the ward looked after us both and joked that Steven would get a call saying a match had been found for him as soon as I could go home.Former van driver Steven said: &ldquoWhen my consultant first said a combined kidney and pancreas transplant could cure my diabetes it was like a dream.The pair, who began dating in Dec&shy&shyember, have had their lives transformed by transplants (Image: SWNS)&ldquoAfter the operation, it felt surreal knowing I had a working pancreas, that my blood sugar levels were normal and I no longer needed insulin injections.Steven, who is registered blind because of his diabetes, added: &ldquoMy blood pressure has improved so it has taken the strain off my eyes and my sight should stabilise.&ldquoHopefully the world will soon be my oyster. I haven&rsquot been away for over five years so I&rsquod love to go on holiday with Michelle.&ldquoShe really understands me and what I&rsquove been through.Michelle thanked the family of the organ donor whose kidney she was given.She said: &ldquoI want them to know that, although they have had an awful loss, their loved one lives on with me and has given me new life.&ldquoTheir relative has given me something magical. They have a place in my heart for ever.

Punters to be rounded up mobile 'drunk tanks' in new crackdown                Paddy Power&rsquos bet on Oz taxes its earningsPaddy Power and British rival Belair agreed terms on a merger in September 2015, with saw 52 percent of the business owned by shareholders from the former and 48 percent by shareholders from the latter.The merger completed in February 2016 but two months later in April, it was announced that 650 jobs in the UK and Ireland would be lost at the company.The new business, which is listed on the London Stock Exchange, still maintains separate brands in the UK, Ireland and Italy.It operates across four isions: online, retail, Australia and the United States.The online ision comprises Paddy Power and Betfair in the UK and Ireland, while the latter also operates an online betting exchange.Together, the companies operate over 600 high street retail shops in the UK and Ireland.In 2017, Paddy Power Betfair's revenue grew 13 percent from the perios year to &pound1.745 billion, while operating profit was up 19 percent to &pound392 million.Announcing the figures in March, it said: European platform integration successfully completed in January 2018 and resource now focused on developing customer-facing products.&nbspThe company added that it would be investing an additional &pound20m in marketing and customer propositions this year to boost the Paddy Power brand in the UK and Betfair brand in international markets.This is a breaking story. More to follow.

title: Weather forecast UK Met Office latest heatwave hot weather august 2018 weekend
story: Freakishly hot weather could hold out through September and possibly into October, according to some long-range forecasters.A plume of warm, sultry air will sweep into Britain during the middle of next week just as the nation starts to cool down.Temperatures could reach their highest so far this summer with the 38.5C (101.3F) record still under threat, experts say.Only Scotland and parts of northern England will escape the sweltering steam-bath although it will be warmer than average across much of the UK.                UK HOT weather forecast: Britain faces 43C temp as HOTTEST spell hits                UK weather forecast: Britain braces for CONTINENTAL SCORCHERJames Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, warned Britain could be facing another lengthy heatwave.He said: &ldquoOur models show we are about to go into another period of prolonged summery weather, there is a growing likelihood we could see another extreme heat surge during the second half of this month.&ldquoIt is not out of the question that Britain will bask in some of the highest temperatures of summer to date, even beating those seen over the past two months.&ldquoThere is every chance this summer will come in as the hottest on record as temperatures rise back into the mid 30Cs at the very least.&ldquoLonger-range projections show the possibility of warm weather continuing into the start of the meteorological autumn and even into October.Britons have been urged to make the most of a brief cooler spell which will bring a drop in temperatures over the next couple of days.UK weather forecast: Britain is set to sizzle as the UK heatwave returns (Image: NETWEATHER)Torrential rain will hammer swathes of the country as a cold front moves in from the Atlantic on Wednesday night.Northern Britain will be first in the firing line before downpours pelt the south and southeast on Thursday morning.The rain will clear through the day making way for much fresher air to bring temperatures down widely, the Met Office said.Meteorologist Bonnie Diamond said: &ldquoQuite an active front will move over Wales and northern England on Wednesday evening bringing some heavy rain.&ldquoThis will move into the southeast of the country through Thursday morning and it will be a much fresher day with maximum temperatures of around 21C (69.8F).&ldquoFriday is looking more unsettled in the north again with a drier, nicer day forecast elsewhere although it will still feel fresher compared to the start of the week.                BBC weather forecast: Temperatures to SOAR &ndash but not before a storm                Four more years of heatwaves on wayUK weather forecast: Temperatures are set to soar back to 30C this week (Image: NETWEATHER)Rain will continue to pelt Scotland and northwestern England over the weekend with sunshine confined to the south, she said.South-eastern England will hold on to the fine weather into next week as temperatures start to head upwards, she added.She said: &ldquoFrom the middle of next week onwards there will be a good deal of dry, bright weather in the southeast as a result this part of the country will be back to warm or very warm temperatures.&ldquoIt is also going to be humid as tropical air moves into southern Britain, later next week we are expecting temperatures in the high 20Cs.&ldquoThe longer-range outlook shows there is a possibility of the warm or very warm weather lasting in the southeast, it will be more unsettled in northern parts of the country.Warm weather will hold out at least until the end of the month meaning Britons will enjoy another bank holiday scorcher.

title: hawaii weather tropical storm lane hurricane track path map latest
story: Tropical Storm Lane: By Sunday morning, winds could be up to 120mph (Image: The Weather Channel )Around 11pm local time last night, Tropical Storm Lane was located about 1,390 miles southwest of the southern tip of Baja California, Mexico.The storm is moving west about 12mph and while still 2,100 miles away from Hilo, Hawaiians are keeping a close eye on forecasts.Last night, the storm had maximum sustained winds of 50mph which are expected to continue strengthening.The Weather Channel forecast said by Saturday &ldquowe could be looking at a category three hurricane.                North Sea HURRICANE: Huge 95mph gales and TORNADOES to batter TOMORROW                Japan weather: Tropical storm Leepi to SMASH southern Japan on Tues...The current track shows Lane due to pass to the south of Hawaii but as these types of storms have shown, they are subject to change at short notice.By Sunday morning, winds could be up to 120mph,&nbsphowever&nbspthe worst of it should occur when Lane is over the open ocean.If the storm stays on track, there is still a chance the edges will knick Hawaii,&nbspan could&nbspbring big swell and heavy rain.Derek Wroe,&nbsplead&nbspforecaster with the National Weather Service in Honolulu, said: &ldquoWarm ocean water is the fuel for hurricanes.Tropical Storm Lane: The current track shows Lane due to pass to the south of Hawaii (Image: The Weather Channel )He added: &ldquoExpect intensification at least into the weekend. By midday Saturday, it should be approximately 1,000 miles southeast of the Big Island.National forecasters said Lane &ldquoseems destined to become a major hurricane like Hector, which passed safely south of Hawaii last week.But forecasters are urging Hawaii residents to watch Lane closely in case of any changes in track.While Hawaii braces itself for hurricane season, it is also battling another natural event: the ongoing eruption of Kilauea volcano.                Hurricane Hector latest: Storm MISSES Hawaii - where will it land?                Foreign Aid budget WILL be used for disaster hit UK territories Tropical Storm Lane: Lane is forecast to strengthen into a hurricane (Image: Getty )Kilauea on Hawaii&rsquos Big Island has been erupting since May 3, sending huge volumes of lava, ash and gas across the island into the atmosphere.The map of the&nbspisland island&nbsphas been totally&nbsprebuild&nbspby the eruption, which has seen vast rivers of lava our across the island and build up a previous bay.Thousands of residents have been displaced and about 700 homes destroyed as the mighty volcano shows its power.Finally, activity seemed to be slowing, as Hawaii Civil Defense has said that activity at the summit of Kilauea has reduced, with fewer earthquakes.The most active of the erupting fissures, Fissure 8, is now &ldquomostly crusted over, according to the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory.However, civil defence warned: &ldquoAlthough a lull in activity continues, it is common for eruptions to go through periods of diminished output, or to pause completely, only to reactivate days or weeks later, or longer.&ldquoActivity could occur at any time. Residents should remain informed and heed Hawaii County Civil Defense messages and warnings.A hurricane has never been recorded striking an active volcano, and results of such an event are unknown.

title: whale massacre sandav gur v gar island faroe islands annual hunt cull whale driving
story: The sea off the village of Sandav&aacutegur turns red (Image: TRIANGLE)The sea off the coast of V&aacutegar island in the Faroes was turned red with blood as the massacre unfolded.The practice, known as whale driving, saw children as young as five take part in the hunt of 180 whales in the village of Sandav&aacutegur.Every summer, hundreds of pilot and beaked whales are killed across the Faroe Islands, a Danish archipelago located hundreds of miles off the Scottish coast between Norway and Iceland.Whale driving on the Faroe Islands dates back to the late 16th century and involve residents herding pods of whales into shallow waters.                Blue whale SLAUGHTERED by Icelandic hunters                 Whale and dolphin SLAUGHTER: 100,000 creatures 'being blown up'They are then killed using a spinal lance that is thrust into the animal's neck to break its spinal cord.While locals have been carrying out the annual hunts ahead of the sparse winter months for centuries, the practice appears shocking and gruesome to outsiders.Cambridge University student Alastair Ward, 22, was visiting the archipelago to celebrate his graduation when he and a friend stumbled across the bloodshed.He said: &ldquoWe were walking round this bay when this family of locals ran over and said 'you're lucky, there's a whale coming'.The whale massacre takes place every summer (Image: TRIANGLE)Local official insist the cull is sustainable despite its gruesome nature (Image: TRIANGLE)&ldquoWe thought it would just be one being dragged in but more and more boats kept appearing on the horizon.&ldquoI couldn't believe how many whales there were. They were driving them into the bay, prodding them with their oars.&ldquoOnce they got close enough, the whole town sprinted in and started hacking at them.&ldquoEven the children were getting involved, pulling on the ropes and jumping on the carcasses.                Iceland whale SLAUGHTER: Fury as new hunting season comes to Iceland                Outrage as Japan harpoons 122 pregnant whales in the name of science&ldquoWe just sat there speechless and a bit upset but you couldn't really pull yourself away.&ldquoThe squealing from the whales was horrible.&ldquoThey were putting hooks on ropes in their blowholes to pull them in and then hacking at them with knives. They didn't die in a very humane way.&ldquoA lot of the locals were all saying how it's the same as farming but I couldn't really agree with that.Villagers attack a whale with a spinal lance (Image: TRIANGLE)The slaughter of whales  off the coast of V&aacutegar island in the Faroes gets under way (Image: TRIANGLE)&ldquoChildren were jumping on top of them. They just have such a different attitude to us because they're brought up on it.The hunt has been criticised in the past by animal rights campaigners who say the ritual is cruel and unnecessary.But local officials insist the hunt is sustainable and ensures the islands, which have limited opportunities for farming, are as self-sufficient as possible.The say each whale provides several hundreds of kilos of meat and blubber, food which would otherwise have to be imported from abroad to the islands at a cost to the locals and the environment.

title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Picture research: Alfie SnellingTHIS Morning, Wednesday:Gok Wan: “Coming up, Ninja nanas, in a minute, John Torode’s in the Lake District at 11.45, and we’ve got the return of the Hawaiian shirt at midday.“First, would you like to live ten years longer?”Ten years? Right now I’m ambivalent abOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rid harry and meghan turbulent
story: Most of the time, they make the Windsors seem a happy and (almost) normal bunch — no small feat.So why oh why is the Palace spin machine making such a spectacular mess with the Markles?Anybody with half a brain could tell, from the moment Prince Harry and Meghan started dating, that her family could turn into a royal pain in the neck.You’ve got a vengeful and jealous half-sister Samantha, who despises Meghan and has been briefing against her for more than a year.She is now telling hacks that she knows Harry and Meghan’s marriage won’t last, which is charming.Then you’ve got Thomas Markle, the dad, an eccentric character who is furious at being “locked out” of his daughter’s life.Barely a day goes by without Mr Markle hurling another negative headline across the Atlantic in the direction of his new son-in-law.Mr Markle insists that, contrary to official briefings, the rift between him and his daughter continues. He says he was told that he couldn’t speak at the wedding and that Harry berated him on the phone for mishandling the Press while he was recovering from a heart attack.The official royal response to these outbursts has been, effectively, to shove their fingers in their ears and shout la-la-la (or lah-lah-lah).The snobby courtiers and hangers-on dismiss Markle père as fame-hungry.That’s not altogether wrong — he is clearly desperate, as he proved by posing for snaps with the paparazzi in the run-up to the wedding.But it’s not good enough to wish he’d just go away.Meghan is now one of the most photographed and sought-after women in the world. Her very well-paid PR flunkies should have seen these familial landmines a mile off and defused them.But they have failed.Thomas Markle is a difficult and proud man, no doubt. But that is why he should have been treated with care, not frozen out.Why did Team Windsor not find him a role and approach him long before the wedding to make sure he didn’t feel excluded.It’s hard not to feel for him.His ex, Meghan’s mother Doria, was hailed as one of the stars of the wedding.Because she’s a black woman, she invited lots of gushing commentary about the monarchy becoming more diverse and modern.Amen to that. But poor old podgy Thomas, an awkward-looking white bloke, has been shunned from his daughter’s nuptials. You can’t blame him for speaking out.The royal courtiers enjoy the adulation the monarchy receives because Prince Harry has been “brave” enough to marry a woman with a complicated background.But the Palace spin machine freaks out when it comes to confronting the reality of Meghan’s parentage.Perhaps they just find it too vulgar.Harry’s PR man is Jason Knauf, an American specialist in “crisis management” having worked for Royal Bank of Scotland. He excels at sending angry letters to journalists he feels have gone too far snooping into Harry and Meghan’s private lives.But he doesn’t seem to have a clue as to how to handle his clients’ grumpy relatives.As a result, the monarchy is facing arguably its worst crisis since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.We are often told how brilliant the Royal Family’s PR is. Part of the new royal spin, in fact, is about how great the royals now are at spin. They have “rebranded” the monarchy for the 21st century, and so on.Look at the blizzard of positive guff accompanying Prince William, Kate, and Harry’s campaign for mental illness last year.They were, it was said, making the younger Windsors seem more touchy-feely.At the moment, however, they don’t seem sensitive enough to speak to Meghan’s suffering in-laws.That’s not what you’d call a good look.The truth is, royal press officers have long got too much credit.The British admire the Queen because she is admirable.Overall, we prefer monarchy to any other system of government. That’s just common sense. It’s nothing to do with any ingenious branding and media strategy.The public also feels that the younger royals deserve a chance.At a time when our country is consumed by Brexit and political arguments, the wedding of Harry and Meghan came as a blessed relief — something we could all celebrate.The couple both came from broken homes, and nobody cared so long as they were happy. That’s all great.   But it’s obvious that Meghan has, as one royal expert put it, “background baggage that needs unpacking”.Insiders now say the treatment of the Markle family has been a “shambles”.This is before we consider the potential PR bombshells that could erupt if and when Meghan’s ex-husband, Trevor Engelson, decides to grant some interviews.The British don’t want to see the monarchy turned into a reality TV soap, as the Markles and Windsors wage a media war with each other.It’s trashy and embarrassing.But unless the Palace can tackle Meghan’s disgruntled kin, that’s exactly what is happening.Maybe we need a changing of the royal PR guard — before it’s too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british gran complained spanish benidorm hotel compensation
story: Freda Jackson, 81, demanded a refund for her Thomas Cook holiday after claiming she was left in tears because it was teeming with rude Spanish natives.The OAP from Blackburn, Lancs, had said: The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising.The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why cant the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays?However, her comments have sparked outrage in Spain, with thousands claiming it was a cynical ploy to cash in.Antonio Toni Mayor Suarez, President of the Benidorm Hoteliers Association, told The Sun Online: Surely this tourist was looking for their tour operator to return the money for their holiday, reflective of the culture of claim that we see, with some claims as inappropriate as the one described by this tourist.Eradicating the culture of claim among the British is something very difficult and something that should be done through cultural and educational context in the United Kingdom.Its legal system of claims has allowed these types of abuses to occur, the biggest example we suffered two years ago with the thousands of fraudulent claims for food poisoning that flooded Spanish hotels.It would be necessary to review the whole system of claims so that only those that are true and those that have involved damage are admitted.Scores of everyday Spaniards have also waded into the debate - echoing Antonios accusations.Martin Esteban said: I would like to remind Mrs. Jackson, that Benidorm is Spain, if she is not happy that she stays in her country, as well as the people of her country who come to get drunk.Rosa Humanes said: These English do not know what to do to have free vacations, adding that now the bargain of gastroenteritis has run out they make bulls*** new claims.Lucia Garcia Sanchez posted: You have to read between the lines. What she wants is for vacations to (be) free.The hotel itself said that Jackson had only made one complaint, and this was about the location of her room, which was changed at her request.Freda has since been offered compensation of £566 from Thomas Cook due to an error informing her about a change to her flights.A Thomas Cook spokesperson told The Sun Online: Due to a system error Ms Jackson was not informed of a change to her flights until six days before departure.We have offered Ms Jackson and her travel companion a gesture of goodwill to try and put things right which we hope she will accept.

title: labour mp refuses six times to say jeremy corbyn is fit to be pm and hints he could be ousted as leader next month
story: Madeleine Moon failed six times when asked to say if the Labour leader was fit to become Prime Minister.She blasted him for dominating newspaper headlines with negative coverage over his controversial trip to Tunisia in 2014.He has admitted he laid a wreath to honour members of the Black September terrorists who killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich 1972 - but refused to apologise to the widows for attending.After pictures emerged of him at the ceremony at a cemetery in Tunis, Mr Corbyn initially denied he was involved - saying he was marking the deaths of 47 people in Israeli airstrikes in 1985.But he has since changed his story several times, and now faces a House of Commons probe over failing to properly declare the trip to the authorities.The Labour boss has come under increasing pressure this week, which comes on the back of the partys ongoing anti-Semitism crisis.And today Ms Moon, the MP for Bridgend, hinted that Mr Corbyn could face moves to oust him as early as Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.She told TalkRadio: “Individuals as leaders come and go. And the party will look at this I am sure extremely forcefully at the next conference.Lets wait and see what conference decides.“Theres always a rule in politics: if youre on the front pages for too long you become the story and thats not good because you miss all the good and effective things that the Labour Party is doing in terms of policy and holding this government to account.”Host Julia Hartley-Brewer asked her: “Do you think that a man who lays wreaths at the tombs of terrorists who have killed innocent people is fit to be the British Prime Minister?”But Ms Moon would only reply: “That will be a decision for the British people.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: callie rogers teen lotto winner dogsitters
story: Callie — who scooped £1.87million aged 16 — was kicked, punched and stamped on by Marie Hinde, 37, and Jade Quayle, 26.They dragged her around a living room “like a rag doll” and left her bloodied and needing hospital treatment.The pair are now facing jail after admitting the assault.It is the latest blow Callie, 31, has faced since her win in 2003.She suffered depression and attempted suicide after blowing her cash on drugs, boob ops and designer clothes.On the night of the attack in July last year she was in a taxi heading to her then boyfriend’s.She told the driver: “Dont worry about your money. I’ve still got £3,000 left — I’m that girl that won the lottery.”Her boyfriend was not at home but Hinde and Quayle, who had been dogsitting, were there.A row developed and they attacked Callie, who felt kicks to her face and stamps to her body, Carlisle crown court heard.She thought she blacked out at one stage of the 2am attack in Whitehaven, Cumbria.The case against Hinde, of Whitehaven, and Quayle, of Cleator Moor, was this week adjourned for sentencing on September 14.Callie spoke out last week about how miserable the lottery win had made her.She had been working as a checkout girl when she won but immediately gave up her job for a life of wild partying.She blew all her money, spending £250,000 on cocaine, £18,000 on three boob jobs and £300,000 on clothes.She also gave at least £500,000 to family and friends and later realised some used her for cash.She told ITV’s This Morning: “It just became too much to cope with... all the stress of having the money. I wanted to go back to having a normalNot knowing who loved me for me and who was using me and who I could trust. Still, at 31, I have trust issues. There were a lot of false people involved.”The mum of three called for the age limit for buying a lottery ticket to be raised to 18 and said: “At 16 you are still just a child. It nearly broke me.”She is now in a relationship and carer for youngest son Blake, six, who has cerebral palsy.The Government is reviewing the age limit of 16 for buying lottery tickets..Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael schumacher moving mega mansion majorca
story: Katia Rouarch confirmed the F1 drivers move to the sprawling pile is imminent in an interview with weekly Swiss magazine L’Illustre.Politician Rouarch, who became mayoress of Andratx in June, told the Lausanne-based magazine: “I can officially confirm Michael Schumacher is going to move in to our municipality and that everything is being prepared to welcome him.”L’Illustre said she had confirmed the news to its correspondent but no-one on the island had been able to say when Schumacher, 50 in January, would arrive or how long his stay would be.It was reported last month that Corinna had bought Real Madrid president Florentino Perez’s Majorcan mansion for nearly £27million.The huge property near Andratx features two swimming pools, a large garden, a helipad, a guest villa and stunning sea views.Aerial pictures show the propertys sprawling garden which features dozens of trees.Schumachers family has remained private about his life since the seven-time F1 champion suffered a catastrophic brain injury while skiing in December 2013. Since then, the family has been based in Switzerland.Michael, 49, and Corinna, who married in 1995, previously holidayed on the island of Majorca before his devastating accident.Michael was put into a medically induced coma for six months after suffering a life-threatening brain injury.The German racing legend is believed to be receiving full-time care at his home.In 2016, his lawyer told a court Schumacher cannot walk in response to speculation in German media about his condition.German tabloid Bild said Corinna had purchased the exclusive property so she could spend holidays there with her children and friends.The house was bought for £22million by building magnate Perez in 2005, but he put it up for sale last year after the death of his wife Mari Angeles Sandoval.The property was put up for sale last year.

title: virgin media broadband workers holes in customers walls
story: Furious internet users have complained of abysmal service from the provider, with one customer claiming that a vast 10in hole left in his wall by an engineer hadnt been repaired in six weeks.Writing on Twitter, Andrew Mabbitt said: So @virginmedia broke my wall on an installation 6 weeks ago, said theyd fix it and never did &amp left me on hold on the phone for one moment and never came back.Why on earth do I pay so much money for this service? Abysmal.Mr Mabbitt, director of cyber-security firm Fidus Information Security, told the BBC that the engineer who botched the installation was incredibly apologetic.But he said the company had failed to follow-up on their promise that it would be fixed.Got a call the next day from Virgin saying theyd be in touch soon to arrange a date and they never called back, he said.Mr Mabbitt added that he also tried to contact the firm via its online chat service - but claims it was not working at that time.British soldier Dom Valentine also complained that a Virgin Media engineer left a large drill bit stuck in his wall for more than a week in his military accommodation.He told the BBC that the engineer drilled into a metal part inside the wall, which caused the drill bit to get stuck.The engineer then apparently tried it from the outside of the building, with little success.He was hitting it with a hammer which has now cracked the bricks on the other side, said Mr Valentine.Virgin Media offered him £20 credit but he said the firm has not followed up on providing a repair.I was told the area manager would get back to me, which he hasnt, added Mr Valentine.A spokeswoman for Ofcom told the BBC that since 1 June the regulator had received 10 complaints about damage to property left by Virgin Media workers and three relating to work done by Openreach.A spokesman for Virgin Media told the Sun Online: “Were already speaking to the small number of customers referenced and some of these issues have already been resolved.The vast majority of the hundreds of thousands of installs we carry out each year are completed to the high standards we expect.

title: 3 year tenancies landlords government
story: The Sun can reveal that Communities Secretary James Brokenshire is backing calls to make three-year terms mandatory across England and Wales despite fierce opposition from private landlords.A formal decision is due to be announced by the Government next week.Scotland implemented ‘indefinite’ tenancies last year.One source told The Sun: “Landlords won’t be able to just chuck out tenants after a year and jack up the rent.James wants to give tenants the security they need through mandatory, three-year leases.”Ministers proposed three-year tenancies in July but said one option was to allow landlords a “voluntary” opt-out.Another was to offer tax breaks to encourage landlords to adopt them.A move to mandatory three-year deals – while allowing tenants a break-clause if they want a shorter deal – will delight campaigners.The private rented sector accounts for 4.7 million people or 20 per cent of households – up 74 per cent in the past decade. Around 46 per cent of 25 to 34 year-olds now live in private rentals as house prices rocket.Some 80 per cent of the tenancies in England and Wales are set at six or 12 months.Charities warned this leaves tenants at the risk of eviction at short notice- and demanded a change.Shelter chief Polly Neate last night said the Government’s decision was “very good news” that would transform the lives of many struggling to make ends meet.She said: “The current renting system is a complete mess, with families teetering on the edge of blink-and-you-miss-it six-month contracts – barely enough time to set your broadband up, let alone see your kids through school.“This problem will not be fixed by giving landlords a tax break to coax them into doing what everyone should be doing anyway.”Shelter earlier this week said 55 per cent of private renters believe longer tenancies would improve their situation.And they claimed two-thirds of renters would think better of a political party that brought in longer contracts.GOT a story? title: housing price slow rate london south east
story: The Office for National Statistics said average prices increased by 3 per cent to £228,000 in the 12 months to August – the weakest annual growth since 2013.But prices in the capital during the year fell by 0.7 per cent.Upmarket Kensington &amp Chelsea saw a 10 per cent drop in June – the biggest monthly fall since current records began in 1995.The ONS added the annual rate of home sales across the UK has dropped to a five year low of 66,000. George Buckley at stockbroker Nomura said a number of “London-specific issues” could be affecting prices in the capital.He said: “Typically when London moves the rest of the country follows with a lag.“But there are reasons to think London is moving in its own orbit relative to the regions – such as Brexit, stamp duty and other increased costs from buy-to-let.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: university isnt the only option for a level students
story: After two years of studying for A-levels, thousands of young people will find out if their hard work has paid off.Whether they’re aiming to start an apprenticeship, take a place at university, or go straight into a good job, there are plenty of opportunities awaiting them – and the prospects are high.The jobs market has transformed since 2010, with over 3.3 million more people in work – on average that’s over 1,000 more people in a job each and every day.And, since 2010, the majority of that employment growth has been in both full-time and permanent roles.Only yesterday, the latest official statistics showed that unemployment has fallen to 4% - which means it’s the lowest it’s been since the 1970s.To put that into context, someone would be well into their 50s today to remember a time of lower unemployment.And this transformation of the jobs landscape is being led by our young people. Yesterdays employment figures revealed that the proportion of young people unemployed (and not in full-time education) is now at a record low of 4.7% for our country - and far lower than for many other developed countries.It sends a significant message out about the drive and innovation of our young people, and the opportunities that our economy offers to them and their future.With our welfare changes this country can now be powered forward by this young generation.Since 2010, youth unemployment has fallen by over 45%, giving 130,000 more young people a job, and a future.Add the fact that wages are on the up and there are more than 829,000 vacancies nationwide, it’s clear that young people are entering the best jobs market in a decade.On average, the number of vacancies has increased by 4,280 each month over the last year, and those vacancies span from construction to technology.So when young people this week are deciding on their next steps, they can think big as there are plenty of opportunities out there for them, from a job with career progression, to taking up an apprenticeship.Look at Daisy, who turned down five university offers to work at global engineering firm JCB designing new equipment, and she didn’t have to go to university to get there.I’m forever being told, and intrinsically understand, that people want to study at different times in their lives, often inspired to do so when they see the practical benefits of their studies.That’s why so many people prefer, and do better, getting a job first and then studying for exams while they work.Even over the last few decades, how the world of education and work are linked has shifted dramatically. People no longer have one job for life, and lifelong learning is becoming more and more commonplace as people dip in and out of education.Many more people up-skill and retrain throughout their career – and this is how the future jobs market will remain vibrant and strong.And when I speak to employers up and down the country, from manufacturers to marketers, what they want are young people with the right attitude, prepared to work and learn. As they say, ‘if you’ve the will, we can give you the skill’.So when young people this week are deciding their next steps, the academic route isn’t the only option.You can now become a solicitor, an accountant or even a nuclear engineer through the apprenticeship route, earning as you learn and without the cost of going to University. Studying a Higher Apprenticeship gives an average wage boost of £150,000 over a working life.When I speak to young people around the country, I’m impressed with the confidence and self-assuredness with which they look to the future, and the range of options they consider beyond traditional routes.Im certainly no job snob. Life teaches you its not where you come from, its where you get to, and work is exactly the same.You can start anywhere and get to the top as Im repeatedly being told by our countrys top entrepreneurs.Top performers in their fields such as Debbie Moore, Jean-Christophe Novelli, Deborah Meaden and Jo Malone, did not go to university and are just a handful of the individuals who show that with drive and determination you can succeed by treading your own path.Its all about getting a break and taking the opportunities that come your way.So best of luck to everyone today, but whatever your results, there are many opportunities and pathways into a successful career.    Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markles thomas markle fashion
story: The news was greeted with surprise and jokes on social media as royal fans suggested names for his brand — including “Markle and Spencer”.But comic Alan Carr said it was more likely to be a budget option and quipped the new venture should be called “Primarkles”.Tubby Thomas, 74, was famously spotted being measured for a suit in staged paparazzi shots before the royal wedding, after Samantha said the media’s snaps made him look “shabby and rubbishy”.She then defended the staged shots during an interview with Good Morning Britain, saying it was only done to make him look better.She added: “The motive, the goal of it, [was because] he had been so unfairly presented. I think photographers purposely looked for the most unflattering photographs.”In the end Thomas had no need for a suit at all, missing Meghan tying the knot with Prince Harry in May after suffering heart problems.The morning suit ended up left on the peg at upmarket Chelsea outfitters Oliver Brown.PR guru Johnno Spence snapped it up for £2,000 and proudly showed off the threads at Ascot.Now Samantha, 53, is insisting her father has caught the fashion bug anyway.She tweeted from her locked account: “So excited about my father’s new #clothing line for men! Will keep you posted!”The news of his planned business venture comes after the former lighting director told pals he has not had “a f***ing dime” from his ­children since retiring, according to the Daily Mirror.And he has complained bitterly in exclusive interviews in The Sun about how he has become estranged from Meghan.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
