title: a level students collect results uk university
story: The pass rate - any grade between an A* and E - fell to its lowest level since 2010 while the A*-C rate was the lowest it has been in four years.But it wasnt all bad news as some of the higher achievers were seen jumping for joy because more than one if four exam results were an A or A*.Meanwhile, it seems less people are applying to university this year as it also emerged only 411,860 have taken up places so far - less than last year.Amid celebrations and commiserations for sixth-formers Ucas figures revealed the acceptance figures are down 1 per cent from the same point 12 months ago.It comes as young people increasingly feel that getting a degree is less important and instead plan to head straight into the workplace.But for the thousands who did apply, they have been nervously checking their results online, and racing down to their schools and colleges to find out how they did.Boys continue to outperform girls at the highest grades, figures show, with 26.6 per cent of boys entries awarded at least an A grade, compared to 26.2 per cent for entries from their female peers.And in total, 26.4 per cent of UK entries were given one of the two top grades - up 0.1 percentage points on 2017.It is the second year in a row that the A*-A pass rate has risen, as the overall A*-E pass rate has also fallen 0.3 percentage points to 97.6 per cent - the lowest level since 2010.The figures come in the wake of a major exams overhaul - with 24 A-level subjects now reformed.One happy teen leading the boys efforts to storm ahead of the girls, with a clean sweep of five A* grades, will fulfil a childhood dream of studying at Cambridge University.Jack Parkinson, from Thorne, near Doncaster, South Yorkshire, will read computer science after his top performance in mathematics, further mathematics, computer science, physics and the extended project qualification (EPQ).The 18-year-old said: After the summer school, I decided I really wanted to go there and Ive been focused on that ever since.Im really looking forward to being around people who have similar interests to me.And an 18-year-old GB kayaker achieved four A-levels while training for his sports world marathon championships.Luke Shaw sat his exams at Norwich School and gained an A* in maths, A grades in chemistry and politics and a B in further maths.He has an unconditional offer to the University of Nottingham where he plans to study economics, potentially with Spanish.As results pour in for this years reformed exams, Rachael Warwick, executive headteacher of Didcot Girls School in Oxfordshire, attacked the changes brought in by the government.She said they were seen as unnecessary by many in the profession and the speed at which they had been brought in made them difficult to implement.She told BBC Radio 4s Today: It has put schools and colleges under immense pressure.Personally I question why that was done and certainly the speed and quality of implementation had a lot to be desired.We would certainly expect in the future a more measured approach to curriculum reform from the Government, and a period of stability.A poll by the Sutton Trust, which questioned around 2,300 children aged 11-16 in England and Wales, found that three-quarters (75%) think it is important to go to university, down from 78% last year and a high of 86% in 2013.More than three in four (77%) of those surveyed this year said they are likely to go into higher education.Figures published by Ucas in July showed that young people in England are more likely to apply to go to university than ever.More than a third (38.1%) of 18-year-olds across the country have applied this year, up 0.2 percentage points on last year.Of the young people who said they they are unlikely to go into higher education, the most common reason was that they do not like the idea or do not enjoy learning and studying (58%), followed by finance (44%).More than a third (35%) said they feel they are not clever enough, while the same proportion said it was not needed for their job plans.Sir Peter Lampl, founder of the Sutton Trust and chairman of the Education Endowment Foundation, said: Its no surprise that there has been a fall in the proportion of young people who think its important to go into higher education.Young people face a dilemma. If they go on to university they incur debts of over £50,000 and will be paying back their loans well into middle age. And in a number of cases they end up with degrees that dont get them into graduate jobs.On the other hand, degree-level apprenticeships are almost non-existent with less than 10,000 available each year compared with over 300,000 university places. There is effectively no viable alternative to university.Jeremy Clarkson had some words of advice for students who fell short of what they hoped to get.He tweeted: Dont worry if your A-level grades arent any good. I got a C and 2 Us.And Im sitting here deciding which of my Range Rovers to use today.And ITV news anchor Alastair Stewart also wished students good luck.He wrote: However you do, remember: in 5 years they wont matter too much in ten, not at all in 20, theyll probably be called something else.Boys have outperformed girls at the top A-level grade for the first time since it was introduced in Northern Ireland.They overtook girls by 0.4 per cent at the A* grade, which was first awarded in 2010.The performance gap between the genders also narrowed at the A*-A grade boundary, and it follows concerted efforts to address the disparity by education authorities.Last year, 26.3 per cent of A-levels scored an A or A*, national figures showed, and the results were predicted to be broadly similar again this year.There have been major changes to A-levels in England, with a move away from coursework and modular exams throughout the course.A Department for Education spokesman said university isnt for everyone and the Government does not want one route to a career to be considered better than any other.That is why we are transforming technical education in this country to put it on a par with our amazing academic system, he said.Students who havent got the results they hoped for can try their luck through clearing.The process works by helping students find out what university courses still have places remaining.Hopefuls are able to search for a course against the subject they are interested in, or the university they want to head to.

title: a level results day memes twitter
story: Teens have been sharing their funny reactions to the big day on under the hashtag #alevelresults2018 - but it seems some of them are far from impressed.Users posted witty captions along with popular images and GIFs from shows like Love Island, the Inbetweeners and Spongebob Squarepants.While some have used the hashtag to wish their peers luck, many have shared amusing jokes with their followers to lighten the mood.One joked: Cant fail your A-levels if you did a BTEC #alevelresults2018Alongside a GIF of Love Islands Wes Nelson dancing, another posted: Me right now dancing in happiness after getting accepted by the uni that was my firm choice #alevelresults2018With a GIF of an owl, another student joked: Me acting surprised in front of my teachers and my family when I’ve failed all my exams knowing full well that I screwed it up months ago #alevelresults2018One user, who shared a photo of Will from the Inbetweeners, said: #alevelresults2018 got me likeTougher exams have meant the number of teens accepted onto uni courses has dropped, as only 411,860 have taken up places so far, 1 per cent down from last year.However, many sixth-formers have been celebrating as A-level students have been awarded the highest proportion of As and A*s since 2012. Those who didnt get the results they wanted can use clearing to get a place at uni.The UCAS process works by helping students find out what university courses still have places remaining.Hopefuls are able to search for a course against the subject they are interested in, or the university they want to head to.

title: nerve racking moment a level students open results live on gmb and not all are pleased
story: Student Niall, from Hull, wanted to go to Cambridge or Edinburgh University to study Russian history.But despite getting an amazing A in German, an A in history and an A in maths, Niall got a B in physics - leaving him short of what he needed to get onto his dream course.He handled the disappointment brilliantly however, telling the presenter: It isnt quite what I needed but its one of those things you cant change isnt it?Sixth-formers across the country are today waking up to their A-level results in the wake of major exam reforms, with around one in four entries expected to be awarded the highest grades.Youngsters who are still seeking university places are likely to face a wealth of choice as institutions scramble to attract good candidates on to their degree courses.University leaders suggested that there could be more people who are using Clearing this year to apply to university for the first time.A snapshot survey suggests that the day before results were due to be released, more than 26,000 courses were available in clearing for students in England only.More than half a million students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland are receiving A-level results today.Last year, 26.3% of A-levels scored an A or A*, national figures showed.The results are likely to be broadly similar again this year.There have been major changes to A-levels in England, with a move away from coursework and modular exams throughout the course.Last year the first grades were awarded in the first 13 subjects to be reformed in England and, among these subjects alone, the proportion of entries scoring at least an A grade fell by 0.7 percentage points to 24.3%.A further 11 subjects have been reformed with the first grades awarded today.Amanda Brown, deputy general secretary of the National Education Union, argued that A-level changes means that students are unable to fully demonstrate what they can do.Changing the assessment of A-levels so they focus on high-stakes exams taken at the end of two years of study does not allow students to properly demonstrate their ability and puts them under huge pressure, she said.Coursework and other non-exam assessments are a better way for students to demonstrate their skills, are less of a memory test, and help lower attaining students and those with special educational needs and disabilities show their achievements.One expert has suggested that the proportion of top grades could drop slightly, by less than a percentage point, due to changes to the exam system, and a major hike in the number of unconditional offers handed out by universities.Mitigating this are a number of factors, including processes put in place by Englands exams regulator Ofqual to ensure that results are comparable and the first cohorts of students to take new courses are not disadvantaged, Professor Alan Smithers of the University of Buckingham said.For those looking for degree places through Clearing this summer, there are suggestions that they are likely to find it is a buyers market.The Press Associations survey shows that, as of Wednesday, 26,350 undergraduate courses were showing up on the Ucas clearing website for students in England.Nine in 10 UK institutions have at least one course listed in Clearing, the survey found.It also shows that three quarters of Russell Group universities, often considered among the best in the country, have at least one course in Clearing, with almost 4,500 courses listed in total.The numbers of courses listed change frequently as different courses are filled, or become available.At the same point last year, the day before results day, there were around 27,715 undergraduate courses in total listed on Clearing with potential availability for students in England.

title: rapper stormzy launches scholarship for two black kids to go to cambridge
story: His new Stormzy scholarship will pay for their entire tuition fees for up to four years - which have now reached £9,250 per year.The Brit award winner will also cover the extra costs of studying at the world-renowned university.The rapper, 25, from Croydon told BBC News today as kids across the country pick up their A Level results: Its so important for black students, especially, to be aware that it can 100 per cent be an option to attend a university of this calibre.The news comes after it was revealed that some Cambridge colleges didnt take a SINGLE black student from 2012 - 2016.The grime star will fund two students this year who will start in October - and another two in 2019.Students can apply online before the end of the month - as long as they are of black ethnicity and are holding an unconditional offer for the uni.And Stormzy, whose real name is Michael Ebenazer Kwadjo Omari Owuo Jr added: Were a minority, the playing ground isnt level for us and its vital that all potential students are given the same opportunity.He made the announcement as part of a visit to his old school, Harris City Academy in Croydon, South London.But Stormzy was keen to stress that its not the only route available for young people deciding what they want to do in life.He said today: “Luckily for myself when I was going through school, I had the academic ability.I was always reminded by my teachers that I was destined, if I wanted, to go down that road and study at one of the top universities.I diverted and ended up doing music so it didn’t happen for me. title: aretha franklin soul singer endured tumultuous childhood to conquer the world and demand respect
story: It is possibly why Barack Obama labelled her music as embodying the connection between African-American culture and the experiences felt by many throughout US history.He told BBC Radio 4 the reason he would take her music to a desert island, over and above almost anyone else's, was because "she'll remind me of my humanity, what's essential in all of us. And she just sounds so damn good."It could be because her life, born to the family of a philandering baptist minister and ending up the female artist with the most entries in the US R&B chart's history, in many ways exemplified the trials and fortunes of many from her background.She was born in the spiritual home of R&B, Memphis, in 1942, to an itinerant preacher and a piano player and singer.Before she was five, the family moved to Detroit where her father had been given the pastorship of a church.But her childhood was not a happy one. Amid rumours of infidelity, her parents separated in 1948 and her mother moved to Buffalo with a son from a previous relationship. A few years later her mother was dead. The job of looking after the young Franklin fell to several women, including one who was known as the "greatest gospel singer in the world", Mahalia Jackson.The world she grew up in was one in which gospel singing took centre stage, and where the growing popularity of her father's driving sermons led to his mission being visited by various performers like Jackie Wilson and Sam Cooke.The young Franklin would accompany her father on the road as he and other singers toured churches - moves that eventually led to her releasing gospel records herself. It may have been because of the unstable nature of life at home that she fell pregnant and had children twice before the age of 15.At 18, she told her father she wanted to follow in Sam Cooke's footsteps and become a pop artist, and after she signed to Columbia she enjoyed a degree of success on the R&B chart.She was managed by Ted White, a man she married in 1961 at the age of 19 and had another child with three years later.White was described by a number of sources as controlling, dealing out domestic abuse on many occasions.In 1970, after their marriage broke down, Jet magazine reported that White was investigated for shooting Sam Cooke's brother, who attempted to protect Franklin when her husband turned up at her house.It was after a move to Atlantic in 1966 she achieved wider success, with her first single with the new label, I Never Loved A Man (The Way I Love You), reaching number one on the R&B chart and the top ten in the US pop chart.It was closely followed up by an adapted cover of Otis Redding's classic hit Respect, which went to number one in the US and made the UK top ten.The release of Lady Soul, in early 1968 - her 14th album - cemented her place in rock and pop history, with hits like Chain Of Fools and (You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman entering the songbook for decades and (Sweet Sweet Baby) Since You've Been Gone showing Franklin herself could co-write big sellers.A cover of Dionne Warwick's I Say A Little Prayer had similar success later the same year. She married again in 1978, to actor Glynn Turman, but they also divorced six years later.The 1980s were a period beset with family tragedy. Franklin's father ended up in a coma after being shot twice at his home and died five years later in 1984.Franklin's brother Cecil, who became her manager after White, died of cancer in 1989, as did her sister Carolyn in 1988 - one of two sisters who regularly featured on her records.Despite her hardships she managed to open up a new audience in the 1980s with the release of the Who's Zoomin' Who album and its accompanying hit, performed with Eurythmics, Sisters Are Doin' It For Themselves.Two years later, she maintained her reputation, in the UK especially, with the George Michael duet I Knew You Were Waiting (For Me) - probably her biggest worldwide hit. By 1979, she had already been given a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, and went on to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1987, awarded a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 1994 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2005.In 2013, Rolling Stone named her as the best singer of all time.Throughout her later career, Franklin suffered accusations she was a diva to deal with. She was regarded as being single-minded in her determination to put her interests first, underlined by her leaving her first two children behind in Detroit with older relatives as she sought success musical elsewhere.

title: ex brexit minister invested 70000
story: NewsEx-Brexit minister invested £70,000 in firm urging people to buy gold as 'insurance' against no-dealSteve Baker was a Brexit minister and is now a member of Jacob Rees-Mogg's European Research Group of eurosceptic ToriesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter16:05, 16 AUG 2018Updated16:09, 16 AUG 2018News (Image: REUTERS)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former Brexit minister invested &pound70,000 in a company that urges customers to buy gold as “insurance” against a no deal Brexit, it was reported today. title: heres pedestrianising parliament square really
story: NewsopinionHere's why pedestrianising Parliament Square is a really terrible ideaIt'll only send the terrorists to TescoShare&nbspByFleet Street FoxColumnist13:44, 15 AUG 2018Updated14:12, 15 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailApart from the individual horror of being mown down by a speeding vehicle, yesterday's terror attack on Parliament was mostly harmless. No-one died. The terrorist was caught alive. There is no martyr, and if the worst they can do is smack their heads against a reinforced anti-terrorist barrier next to the most heavily-guarded building in Britain then, frankly, there's not a lot to lose sleep over.  Except there is, because as with every terror attack the hardest questions that must be asked are not, while official knees jerk to protect themselves.  Attacks on Parliament bring home to MPs that they are targets for those who take exception to their views, their politics or their existence. It's natural that after the second car-based attempt at mass murder on their place of work in 17 months, they would start to think that cars might be the problem. Only we don't say men are the problem, even though every single terror attack carried out on our shores of late has been conducted by people with testicles. The Islamists who have attacked us may have been Muslims, people of colour, slightly-thick zealots, and one-time petty criminals, but we have not and will not outlaw all such people for the crimes of a few. Boris Johnson would be stuffed, for a start. Yet some say it's time to pedestrianise Parliament Square. Because terrorists are never on foot, are they?   Terrorists have never been in cars, then got out of them to kill someone, have they?    Terrorists have never targeted places where all their potential victims are walking or sitting down, have they?   Terrorists are always the driver, aren't they?  Terror attacks often lead to changes, many of them useful. When the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel in Brighton it led to stringent security measures for party political conferences. After 6 were killed and 50 injured at the Westminster Bridge terror attack, Theresa May promised another &pound50m for counter-terrorism, having earlier been criticised for cuts.  And let's not be too architecturally-conservative about Parliament Square. It was laid out only in 1868, around the same time as the Victorians rebuilt the Houses of Parliament. It is a space owned by the Greater London Authority, which has the power to make bylaws for it, and has used this power in recent years to repeatedly curb the right to protest.  While there is a right to assembly on any public highway, on the roads around Parliament you must ask for police permission. So, on the face of it, pedestrianising the area - putting even the roads under local authority control, banning cars which happens anyway for approved protests, and keeping weapons-on-wheels away from the seat of our democracy - may seem like a sound idea. But it isn't.  Manchester Arena is not a public space, is privately-owned, and keeps its concert-goers away from vehicles. Salman Abedi still managed to blow himself and 22 others to pieces, killing and injuring huge numbers of children.   Abedi used a backpack and a suitcase. Parliament Square attracts millions of tourists a year, most of them with backpacks and suitcases.  Perhaps police and politicians would like bollards at the entrance to the square to include x-ray scanners, to catch those carrying bombs or knives in their backpacks?  In which case, we can look forward to everyone with a penknife or nail scissors being stopped, liquids being bagged and belts and shoes removed at the entrance to the square, just as they already are when you attempt to enter Parliament itself. And anyone who wishes to stage a protest or go to the TV studios at Millbank to criticise the government, will not only have to seek formal approval but be questioned as to their purpose on the way in and the way out. At this uncomfortably-authoritarian juncture, it might be wise to remind ourselves of the few times in recent history that Parliamentarians have actually been attacked.  Jo Cox MP was shot and stabbed on the roadside in Birstall, West Yorkshire in 2016 while on her way to meet constituents.  Stephen Timms MP was stabbed twice at a constituency surgery in a library in Beckton, east London in 2010.  More recently, Conservative life peer David Prior was the victim of a pig blood-based graffiti attack in his own home by an angry ex-girlfriend. When a brick was thrown through Angela Eagle's office, Stella Creasy was threatened with rape and Jess Phillips given death threats, it happened either in their own constituencies or online. And who could forget when deputy Labour leader John Prescott was egged outside a theatre in Rhyl, north Wales, in 2001 when on his way to a political rally.  As yet, no Islamist has yet come within 10 yards of a Parliamentarian at Parliament. Those who have launched attacks outside have not got in, and it has become quite apparent that while cars are good at killing pedestrians, they are rubbish at getting past armed police officers, metal barriers and brick walls.  Of course a Parliamentarian could be outside on his bike, as others were yesterday, or walking over Westminster Bridge, or coming through the gate at the wrong time. So could any one of a thousand other humans, and it is not for the public's sake anyone has suggested banning vehicles.  It has been suggested purely to look like something is being done - even though that thing would not deter a single terrorist. We have yet to hear of an incident averted because a devoted Islamist saw a 'keep off the grass' sign. They are not known for being law-abiding, and it should be noted that this latest attack involved an illegal turn on the wrong side of the road, in clear contravention of the Highway Code.  You can say this for cars being used as weapons - they tend to at least keep the driver alive. And if you ask any counter-terrorism officer what he'd like most after a terror attack, he'd say someone to interrogate.  He might further point out that, in his ideal world, the terrorists come to him. They choose the most-guarded, secure and bristling-with-police-officers building in the country, and run at it one at a time, almost as though they were idiots.  Parliament is a place that can handle terror. Blocking it off to cars does not stop terrorists - it just moves them down the road, to Tesco or the Tower of London or Top Shop. And there isn't a person on the planet who can't see that an attack on soft targets is not only easier for even the most stupid of zealots to manage, but it'll kill an awful lot more people.   Pedestrianisation is the go-to solution for every politician from the local town hall to Downing Street. Banning cars is the only way they can think of to boost local cafes, cut pollution and, now, protect democracy. Never mind that business rates, car manufacturers and sanity might all have more to do with it.  The ability to drive, in cars, taxis or buses, and to walk or cycle unhindered, through Parliament Square does two important things. First, it means millions of us get to see the place close up. On visits, school trips, holidays, the daily commute and in tiny glimpses on our way to somewhere else, we are reminded it is there, and that it is ours. If it were pedestrianised it would be seen only by those who seek it out. And secondly, it tells the terrorists - these dense meat-sacks who could not in any other situation terrify a wet kitten - that we are unmoved. Our democracy has survived worse, and it will survive them.

title: titanic brexit mash up been
story: NewsThis Titanic Brexit mash-up has been called an 'absolute masterpiece'This comic masterpiece stars Boris Johnson, Michael Gove and Nigel FarageShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent14:47, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere's not been many laughs when it comes to Brexit but the creators of this clip have hit upon some comedic gold. Boris Johnson said back in 2016 that Britain will make a titanic success of Brexit.  But while the ex cabinet minister may have been using the word to mean big, he seems to have forgotten that for most of people Titanic refers to a ship which sunk in 1912 when it hit an ice berg.  It is also notable that the ship was believed to be unsinkable - and then it sank. You can draw your own conclusions as to how that might compare to Brexit.  The comic video, which uses scenes from the 1997 film starring Leonardo Di Caprio and Kate Winslet, features David Cameron as captain of the sinking ship.    He is heard to say I do not think it would be right for me to be the captain that steers our country to its next destination, in reference to his resignation following the referendum, before the water bursts in and he disappears from view. Brexiteers Boris Johnson, Michael Gove and David Davis are seen in the ship's navigation room, while the spectre of Nigel Farage floats in the background.  Meanwhile Jeremy Corbyn is seen as one of the violinists in the orchestra which famously kept on playing while the ship sank.   In the video created by Josh Pappenheim, Foreign Secretary Mr Johnson is also shown as a child who manages to get on a lifeboat to escape.     The pound is seen falling - as it did in the wake of the poll.  While the 42%/ 52% which was the result of the vote is projected on to the two halves of the ship.

title: ron stallworth explains how became
story: NewsHow Ron Stallworth became the first black member of the KKK - and even became head of his local branchAhead of the release of Spike Lee film BlacKkKlansman, the undercover cop tells how he spent a year infiltrating the Ku Klux KlanShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByOliver Milne21:15, 15 AUG 2018Updated12:58, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTo his fellows in the Colorado Springs branch of the KKK , Ron Stallworth was in many ways the perfect Klansman. Always on time, well organised and, based on all the conversations the Ku Klux Klan’s members had with him, a powerful advocate for their hateful racist politics. What they didn’t know was that Ron was a black police officer. In 1979, Officer Stallworth, then 29, spent a year infiltrating the KKK and exposing their links with the police, military and organised crime. His audacious scheme, which started when he saw an advert in his local paper asking for potential KKK members, has inspired what some critics have called “the most important film of the year”, BlacKkKlansman. But in many ways, the truth is even stranger than Spike Lee’s movie makes it out to be. Working as an intelligence officer for the Colorado Springs Police Department, Ron was the only black officer on the force. So he took the rising tide of racist violence very seriously. And when he answered that advert, picking up the phone to talk to local KKK organiser Ken O’Dell, Ron knew he was risking more than embarrassment if they found out who he was.  America was gripped by far-right terrorism in the 1970s. In 1971, KKK members used dynamite to blow up ten buses which were to be used to desegregate schools in Pontiac, Michigan. In the months when Ron was planning his scheme, five communist protestors demonstrating in a Death To The Klan march were killed by the KKK and the American Nazi Party in the Greensboro massacre in North Carolina. In 1980, four black women were shot in Chattanooga, Tennessee, after a KKK rally. Just six months, later Michael Donald, age 20, was lynched in Alabama, his body found hanging from a tree. With this kind of bigoted violence going on, it’s fair to say that Ron knew the kind of character he was supposed to be playing when trying to ingratiate himself with the KKK’s O’Dell. Ron said: “I eventually spoke with him over the phone responding to that ad, and he explained to me that he was starting a Klan chapter in Colorado Springs and was looking for new people. “So I told him that I was a white man, that I hated blacks, Jews, Mexicans, Asians. That I thought the white man had not gotten a fair deal in this country. “[That] I was really upset because my sister had dated a n***** and it offended me that his black hands had touched her white body. And, as a result, I wanted to join the group and do what I could to put a stop to all of this nonsense.”  That was all it took – Ron, who now lives in El Paso, Texas, with his wife, was in. But very quickly he knew he was going to get caught if he couldn’t solve a major problem. How could he, a black man, walk into the public meetings of a large and violent racist organisation dedicated to seeing him back in chains? He was fine dealing with them over the phone, but he knew that when it came to having face-to-face meet-ups, he couldn’t go himself. So he drafted in his friend, Chuck, who worked in the drug squad, to be Ron Stallworth in person. It was also at this point that Ron realised he had – perhaps shortsightedly – signed his own name on his first letter to the KKK. However, it wasn’t just the practical problems holding up Ron’s investigation. Senior officers took a while to be convinced of its merits. “They felt like they couldn’t lose investigators to a bunch of nonsense like ‘men running around in sheets’,” said Ron. But with no signs of America’s racial violence subsiding, senior officers eventually agreed. Ron arranged to meet O’Dell, who was a serving soldier, at a bar near Fort Carson military base. He sent Chuck in wearing a wire, and guided him through the tricky conversations. “That’s how we conducted this investigation over the next eight or nine months or so,” Ron said. “I did most of the talking on the phone with these individuals, and when it came time for physical contact, the face-to-face meeting, I would send the white officer in posing as me.”  After months of phone calls and secret meetings, the infiltration was going so well that, incredibly, O’Dell recommended that Ron be made the head of the Colorado Springs branch of the KKK. He was put in touch with the hate group’s leader, David Duke. At one point – clearly confident that his plan hadn’t been rumbled – he even asked the KKK’s leader about the threat of infiltration. Ron explained: “I said, aren’t you afraid of an undercover police officer infiltrating your organisation or maybe a black man calling you up and pretending to be white?” “He said no, he wasn’t fearful of that at all, because he could always tell when he was talking to a black person.” Pushing his luck, Ron asked how Duke knew that he wasn’t black. “He said, you don’t talk like a black man. You talk like a very smart, intellectual white man. I can tell by the way you pronounce certain words.” Then, in an incident that seems more like far-fetched movie plot than real life, Ron – in his role as a serving police officer, rather than an undercover agent – met Duke in person. He was tasked with protecting the so-called Grand Wizard while he delivered a racist rant in public. He said: “I went and introduced myself to David Duke without giving him a name and told him I would do everything I could to protect him, even though I didn’t agree with him. We shook hands and I became his bodyguard.” Ron’s investigation in many ways highlighted his worst-possible fears. He found Klansmen in all walks of life, from local shop owners to school teachers and his neighbours.

title: amazon drivers abusive note left
story: NewsAmazon driver's abusive note left for single mum has left her 'too scared to answer the door'Lisa, Jane Watson, from Warrington, Cheshire, was unable to be there for the package because her mother was in hospital with a broken hipShare&nbspByRachel BishopJohn Glover13:16, 16 AUG 2018NewsLisa Jane Watson was astonished to find the note (Image: Deadline News)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA single mum was left 'frightened' after an Amazon driver angrily accused her of messing him about when she wasn't home to collect a package. The driver is under investigation after Lisa Jane Watson said he left her an official missed delivery note that had been scrawled on in blue biro: Pick up yer fone in future. The delivery driver added: Messed me about. You wasted half an hour cos of you. Lisa Jane Watson, from Warrington, Cheshire, was unable to take delivery of the package because her mother was in hospital with a broken hip. Lisa, 45, says she received 13 calls from an unknown London landline around the time of the delivery.  She answered on three occasions but the line was empty each time, meaning she ignored subsequent calls. The primary school teaching assistant says the disgusting note has made her scared to order online again and she has told her children not to answer the door. Lisa, an Amazon Prime customer, ordered Yankee candle plug-in refills on Monday and was told to expect delivery on Tuesday. She said: I had a couple of phone calls around lunchtime, which came up on my mobile as a London number. I ignored the first call but when they called back I answered it, the call then ended. They called again and I answered but again the call ended.  I then suspected it was a scam as it was a London number. I was then called numerous times but I declined each call. It was really frightening to receive so many calls like that. She added: I then arrived home at teatime to the note through the door and my parcel was left with a neighbour. As a single mum with two young girls. It's quite frightening that there is a driver out there that is that angry with me. I'm scared to order anything again. When I saw the same neighbour he left it with getting a delivery, I was terrified that he [the driver] may come over to confront me. My safety chain is always on now and I've told my girls not to answer the door. I got enough on my plate without all this added stress. Amazon sent Lisa an email which read: I would like to express my sincerest apologies for the note that our driver has left when attempting delivery of a recent parcel.

title: builder tears down brand new
story: NewsBuilder forced to tear down brand new £250,000 house because of what was underneath itIt could only be the start of Paul Mager's trouble, as the local council says it received no prior approval for the demolition workShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKeane Duncan10:15, 16 AUG 2018Updated13:56, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brand new house thought to be worth at least &pound250,000 is being torn down because it was put up on top of a major water main. Developer Paul Mager said he didn't know the underground pipe was there until after the two-storey, detached house was already built. He decided to matters into my own hands and tear down the house in Tetney, Lincolnshire, amid a row with Anglian Water that he didn't think he would win. But it could only be the start of his trouble, as the local council says it received no prior approval for the demolition work, Grimsby Live reports.  Bulldozers moved in to demolish the executive house on Wednesday morning, sparking bemusement from neighbours. Mr Mager said the construction work could have ruptured the main, which serves homes across Cleethorpes and Waltham, leading to a major disaster. The head of Mager Homes Limited said: The detached house that is as we speak coming down has been built on the main water main from the Tetney Blow Wells. So that detached house has been built on the main water main artery that runs into Waltham and Cleethorpes. So to cut a long story short, having tried to do a deal with Anglian Water, it became apparent that the best thing to do was to take it down and re-site it.  It's a bit more complicated than that. But I have had a major row with Anglian Water and it looks like I was going to lose so I took matters into my own hands. Built on top of a main taking water from Tetney Blow Wells nature reserve, the house has never been occupied. It was approved in 2016 by East Lindsey District Council as part of an application for seven properties on Humberston Road. Mr Mager said: In order to avert that puncture taking place, the quickest thing was to take it down in order to avoid any damage to Anglian Water property. That little corner will be flattened and we will resubmit a planning application to redevelop in a different way.  I am not going into the argument with Anglian Water. But basically either the house had to move or the main had to move. For piece of mind, I decided to move the house on my own timetable. Mr Mager said the main only came to light after the house had been constructed. He said: I have been doing it all my life. If we had known it was there, we would never have done it. The ongoing demolition came as news to East Lindsey District Council's planning department, who said no prior permission had been given for the work. Development control service manager Chris Panton said: “This is the first we have heard of the demolition currently ongoing on Humberston Road, Tetney. story: NewsCocktails based on Brit regions unveiled – and the ingredients will shockA poll of 2,000 Brits found the nation’s favourite flavours in each region, with the results being boiled down by expert mixologists into unusual alcoholic concoctionsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRichard Jenkins16:06, 16 AUG 2018Updated16:08, 16 AUG 2018NewsA new range of extremely British cocktail recipes has been releasedGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new range of extremely British cocktail recipes has been released – featuring tea, curry and BOVRIL. A poll of 2,000 Brits found the nation’s favourite flavours in each region, with the results being boiled down by expert mixologists into unusual alcoholic concoctions. Almost three in 10 Brummies believe the flavour of a Balti best represents their area, leading to the ‘Brummie Sweet Spice’ cocktail being born – also containing dark chocolate, Bitters and Cr&egraveme de P&ecircches liqueur. And for gravy-loving Manchester, mixologists created the ‘Rock My Manchester Gravy Boat’, a beer-based cocktail topped off with Bovril and raspberry liqueur. Louise Lynch, Product Developer for Beers, Wines and Spirits at Sainsbury’s says “Having worked in the drinks industry for many years, I’m surprised that we’ve never seen a British cocktail earn its place amongst the classics.  “It seemed like an obvious solution for us to use our new range of cocktail ingredients to create a bespoke collection of cocktails the nation can be proud of. “Our cities are famous for their identity and we’re confident that these creations represent the charm and character of our home-grown regions.” The Edinburgh Irn Punch takes inspiration from the iconic Old Fashioned, and mixes whisky with Scotland’s other famous export Irn Bru, served with a side of shortbread. The supermarket giant worked with the London Cocktail Club to invent the bold new flavours, culminating in ‘The Great British G&ampTea’. Combining two of Brits’ greatest loves – gin and tea – the wacky drink mixes tea with London Dry Gin, a dash of cassis liqueur and a spoonful of blackberry jam – and is best served with a custard cream.  JJ Goodman, the founder of London Cocktail Club, said “We had a lot of fun creating cocktails which represent these great cities. “The key for me was to keep the drinks simple, but also creatively interesting so they can not only be re-created at home but also feel like a taste of home. “Sainsbury’s has done a great job with their new range of cocktail ingredients, which help to keep the cost down when experimenting in mixology and I hope this encourages more people to get inventive with their creations.”

title: couple unrecognisable after losing whopping
story: NewsCouple are unrecognisable after losing a whopping 12 STONE in less than a yearMatt and Naomi Opie from Plymouth say that they struggled with their weight after their son was diagnosed with ADHDShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMiles O'Leary11:03, 16 AUG 2018NewsThe pair joined their local Slimming World branch (Image: Matt Opie)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA husband and wife who once gorged on five takeaways a week have shed almost 12 STONE between them in just under a year. The transformation first came into fruition after Matt Opie, who topped the scales at nearly 16 stone, thought he was going to 'die' running after his son at their local park in Plymouth. Desperate to make a change to their lives, he and his partner Naomi, decided to head to their local Slimming World. Since they embarked on their weight-loss journey, the couple have said that their marriage has improved and has made them even better parents to their boy, Jack. It's been no easy feat and Matt was anxious at first about taking the plunge with so many other women around him aching to trim down.  Speaking to Plymouth Live , Matt said: When I first went, I walked in and there were 40 women in there, and perhaps two or three men, and I just thought, this isn't a man thing to do.   That's what people would think - but it's changed our lives. When I started, I was 15 stone, 11 pounds, Matt explained. I've managed to lose four stone - I had diabetes as well and that's gone. It's taken me 10 months. It sounds a bit funny, but we were laying in bed the other night and we were saying about all the extra room we've got now. We've lost more weight than what Naomi weighs now. You would think there were three of us in this bed. It's absolutely crazy. Naomi's journey is quite remarkable - she's shifted seven and a half stone and has not put on a single pound since she started weighing in at Slimming World last year. Matt reflected on what made him want to change his life.  My son has problems and we were seeing him at school, I was trying to get him but he was having a meltdown and I thought I was going to die having to try and run after him, he explained. As soon as that happened, I knew things had to change. My son has been diagnosed with ADHD - and now I can do more stuff with him. When he was going to the park and I was trying to run after him, I was out of breath. It may seem stupid to some people, but we are having more fun as a family now, doing more stuff together that we wouldn't do before like taking selfies. You should see the photos we had previously. Now, we're just taking selfies with everything. It feels like we're making up for lost time, Matt admitted.  We didn't really have family photos up before, now we're going to places like the zoo and taking lots of photos. Matt said the couple's weight climbed as problems got worse with their son. Struggling to get him to bed, they felt too exhausted to cook - and relied on their local takeouts to keep them going. But that only fed their weight problems - and made them feel exhausted and stressed. I was having four or five takeaways a week, sometimes twice a day, Matt said. Matt says - a diet full of salad and vegetables and swapping out chips for jacket potatoes. I eat salad and veg every day now, Matt said. Jacket potatoes - in my 37 years I had never eaten one until I started Slimming World and now I love jacket potatoes. We live on the third floor and we have a lift. For the last year, I've probably only used it three times. I would definitely advise any man to do Slimming World - it's changed my life. It changes every part of your life.

title: cycling work one most effective
story: AdvertorialWhy cycling to work is one of the most effective ways to lose weightJust 30 minutes per day is all you need, evidence suggestsShare&nbspByHolly Thatcher11:00, 15 AUG 2018Updated13:27, 16 AUG 2018AdvertorialGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are many reasons it makes sense to cycle to work – from reducing your impact on the environment to improving your overall health. And evidence suggests it's one of the most effective ways to lose weight and keep in shape. Obesity is now a major issue in the UK. Put simply, we eat more and move less than our parents did. 26.9 per cent of UK adults are classed as obese, compared with 3% of adults in 1970. This is largely because many of us are now taking on far more calories than we realise , and leading more sedentary lifestyles. According to the Department of Health , a brisk walk burns 150 calories per half hour, while a moderately challenging cycle consumes 180 calories in the same amount of time. It's one of several reasons why cycling trumps most other forms of exercise if you're trying to achieve weight loss and better levels of overall fitness. Why cycling? Unlike running, cycling is a reasonably low-impact activity. This is great for people just getting into exercise, where the advice from doctors is to start off slow and build up. And of course, the fitter you become, the harder you can work: cycling is ideal for a wide range of ages and abilities. But it's also proven to be extremely effective. Researchers use a measure called metabolic equivalents (METs) in studies to define the value of exercise. While slow walk uses 2.0 METs per hour, slow cycling uses 4.0 METs per hour, and moderate cycling 6-10 METs per hour. Cycling is one of the easiest types of exercise to work in your daily routine, simply by cycling to work.  The NHS says that to get the best boost to your cardiovascular health is to spend around 150 minutes a week cycling – that's just 30 minutes per working day. So unless your workplace is next to your home, you should easily see some health benefits.  Wednesday, August 15, 2018 is also this year’s annual Cycle to Work Day . The UK’s biggest cycle commuting event is encouraging all cyclists – from newbies to lycra-loving regulars – to abandon their usual means of transport and get on their bikes.   Those planning to take part are being encouraged to share their plans at cycletoworkday.org and use the #cycletoworkday hashtag. There are all sorts of prizes on offer and so far, 250,000 miles of commute have been pledged. For more information on Cycle to Work Day, visit cycletoworkday.org. Why skipping the train may help you feel better   Research suggests that regular physical activity promotes mental wellbeing. When you cycle (or do any vigorous exercise) your body produces endorphins which can make you feel relaxed and optimistic. Exercise also helps reduce the body’s stress hormones adrenaline and cortisol. Many of us face a long journey to work, which makes cycling all the way impractical. But it is of course possible to cycle part of the journey, and the health benefits of this are still considerable. One excellent option is cycle to your local station rather than driving. You can lock your bike there and commute as usual. Alternatively, folding bikes are allowed on most train services (non-folding bikes are often not), which allows you to cycle at both ends of your commute.  The Carrera Transit Folding Bike , &pound320, is one of many adult bikes with 30 per cent off at Halfords. It features a lightweight aluminium frame and a Nexus hub gearing system for easy maintenance and an easier fold. Get some help early on  Getting healthy is great, but lots of people tell themselves they aren't fit enough to cycle. The truth is that everyone has to start somewhere and modern technology can make the route to health easier. If you're worried about that, or perhaps want a little help on steep hills, then an ebike could be the answer. An ebike has a built-in battery which can be recharged using any mains socket. An electrically-driven motor will then help when you need it, keeping your pace steady and helping on hills. The range of an ebike varies based on the capacity of the battery, weight of the rider and type of terrain you're cycling but expect 30 to 60 miles of assisted range on them, depending on the model.  For example, the Carrera Crosscity E Electric Folding Bike , &pound850, has a battery range of around 30 miles. For most people, this is more than enough for their commute. You can take a folding bike on trains and buses in most cases (check with your local operator), so you have the flexibility to decide how you commute. Not feeling like getting on hot public transport? No problem, jump on the bike instead.  If you're not using public transport then you can opt for a non-folding eBike. The Carrera Crossfire-E Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound1,000 (save &pound250), has a motor that provides up to 60 miles of pedalling assistance on a single charge and will propel you on to speeds of 15.5mph. Its lightweight alloy frame and 8-speed gearing will also help you out when riding uphill. You might just catch the cycling bug   If you stick at that NHS target of 150 minutes a week you’ll start to feel better, you may lose weight and you’ll find your stamina improves. All in all, it has the potential to do wonders for your overall wellbeing. If Cycle to Work Day gives you the cycling bug, then you may decide to upgrade your bike. One thing to consider when choosing a new bike for your commute is how you'll use it outside of work. Are you interested in getting up some speed? Do you fancy trying some off road trails? Then you won't necessarily want to pick a folding bike. If you're cycling the whole way then you might want to look into a road bike or hybrid. These are lighter than other bikes and offer the chance to get up some real speed.  The Boardman SLR 8.6 , &pound550, is a great choice. Its aluminium alloy frame makes it great for zipping along and the 16-speed gears will help make light work of hills, too. Keep in mind that road bikes have thin tyres and are often slick, which means they might not be best suited to use in the rain. A hybrid on the other hand is a perfect balance between speed and accessibility. Hybrid bikes take elements from road bikes and mountain bikes, so they are a great choice if you are looking for something that's great on the roads but also suitable for some slightly rougher terrain.  When it comes to hybrids, we love the Carrera Parva Hybrid Bike , &pound200 (save &pound100), which boasts 21-speed Shimano Tourney gears and Tektro V-brakes for improved stopping power. Look after your safety as well as your health  If you're planning to cycle to work, make sure you invest in a decent helmet - wearing one reduces the risk of serious head injury by nearly 70 per cent. The range of helmets on offer nowadays is huge, varying from ultra light weight helmets that make you feel like you're wearing nothing, chic and sophisticated helmets ideal for the commuter - to ultra high tech smart helmets that connect to your phone.  The Livall MTL Bluetooth Enabled Smart Helmet , &pound69, has LED indicators and an intelligent SOS alert system which connects to your phone via Bluetooth and will send a distress signal to loved ones with your location in the event of a sudden or unexpected movement. You will also need bike lights if you're cycling after dark. Grab the Cateye Bike Light Set , &pound17 (save &pound8), and you're good to go. Even if it's not night time, many cyclists like to keep lights on all the time for extra visibility. Get your heart healthy and happy

story: AdvertorialExclusive new research reveals Britain’s public toilets are vanishing at a staggering rate - and here’s whyDomestos and the Daily Mirror are teaming up to address the shortage of public facilities, with the new Use Our Loos campaignShare&nbspByRichard Innes15:43, 16 AUG 2018AdvertorialBritain's public toilets are quickly disappearingGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey have been a much-valued feature of British high streets for more than 160 years. But public loos are being wiped out at a staggering rate as councils struggle with government budget cuts. More than a QUARTER of public toilets have disappeared since the turn of the century, according to data obtained under Freedom of Information laws. According to the new information - supplied by council areas across the UK - the total number of public toilets across the country has dropped from 3,084 in 2000 to 2,290 in 2018. That is a fall of nearly 800. And authorities in Bolsover, North East Derbyshire, and Wokingham admitted they no longer had ANY council-run loos. In London, of the councils that provided information, the number of public loos was down from 197 in 2000 to just 132 today. The rest of England saw a fall from 2,400 to 1,534, while in Wales numbers had more than halved from 504 to 243. Scotland was down from 759 to 421 while Northern Ireland dropped from 95 to 84.  Campaigners say the problem leaves people with nowhere to go when they need to go and it is affecting everyone from outdoor workers such as builders as well as pregnant women and parents with children. Toilets that can be easily found and used are essential for the elderly and disabled. And with one in five people above 40 suffering from an over-active bladder, the lack of public facilities can make some reluctant to leave their homes due to the risk of being caught short. It is not a legal requirement to provide public lavatories and so when councils aren't feeling flush, toilet blocks are often targeted first when it comes to cuts. A typical toilet block is estimated to cost between &pound12,000 to &pound15,000 a year to maintain. But Domestos believes that clean, safe toilets should be within everyone’s reach. That is why it is launching the nationwide Use Our Loos initiative to tackle the demise and unlock loos in local coffee shops, cafes, restaurants and bars across Britain’s towns, cities and villages.  The scheme is supported by The Daily Mirror, which is urging local shops and businesses to sign up, throw open their cubicles and make their toilets available to non-customers. As part of the initiative, Domestos is also partnering with The Great British Public Toilet Map – an interactive street map that shows users where their nearest public toilet is and which businesses have signed up to the scheme. The map will be regularly updated as new businesses join. Domestos also plays a role in the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan’s aim to get 25 million people across the world access to a clean and safe toilet by 2020. Domestos has partnered with Unicef, the world’s leading children’s organisa&shytion, since 2012 and has already helped 10 million people around the world get cleaner, safer toilets.  Raymond Martin of the British Toilet Association which campaigns for better public facilities, has praised the initiative, saying it will increase visitors to Britain’s high streets. He says : “As human beings we all have to eat, drink, sleep, breathe and go to the toilet,” he said. “Having access to a clean hygienic toilet is absolutely vital for our everyday life and activity. Rebecca Light, Domestos Senior Brand Manager, says: “In the UK the problem is locating a public toilet. An estimated 2.3 billion people worldwide lack access to clean, safe sanitation. This comes with significant health risks, including diarrhoea, which kills one child every two minutes. It’s vital we change this – and quickly.”

title: government worker bound gagged chair
story: NewsGovernment worker 'bound and gagged to chair by sexist colleagues' LOSES bullying and harassment caseDeeAnn Fitzpatrick claimed a racist and misogynistic culture within her office drove her to contemplate suicideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCharlie Gall06:41, 16 AUG 2018Updated07:30, 16 AUG 2018NewsDeeAnn Fitzpatrick says she was bound and gagged at work in 2010 (Image: BBC)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA government worker who claims she was tied to a chair and gagged by colleagues who bullied and harassed her has had her case thrown out. DeeAnn Fitzpatrick, 49, accused fellow fisheries workers of mocking and targeting her in a campaign of sexist harassment. The Canadian woman claimed a racist and misogynistic culture within the Marine Scotland office in Scrabster drove her to contemplate suicide. But an employment tribunal has rejected her claims despite a photo showing her gagged and taped to a chair appeared to back up her claims, the Daily Record reports. That evidence was time-barred.  In an earlier hearing in Aberdeen in June, Ms Fitzpatrick alleged she was taped to a chair and gagged by colleagues in 2010. The tribunal heard how she was bombarded with fake Valentine's Day and birthday cards she believed came from male colleagues A message in one called her an “old troll” and another warned her about trying to “climb the ladder of success”. Ms Fitzpatrick told the tribunal the harassment was so bad she considered taking her own life and contacted an assisted suicide clinic. She told the tribunal: “When I first started getting the cards, it made me feel awful. But as they continued, yes it’s affected my self-esteem. “It’s actually made me become a recluse - I stay at home, I have gone more into myself. With everything going on, I contacted Dignitas in Switzerland. I had enough.” Ms Fitzpatrick, who has worked for Marine Scotland since 2006, was struggling to grasp the tribunal’s verdict.  She said on Wednesday night: “It is difficult when you spend your entire career fighting racism, misogyny and bullies. “Then to make matters worse when you report the incidents, you are the one that is being targeted by an ongoing campaign by senior management because you exposed what they have worked very hard to hide.” The Scottish Government put up one witness, Judith MacKinnon, its head of people advice, who has over 25 years experience in human resources. MacKinnon took up the job last year but said those who dealt with Ms Fitzpatrick’s complaints were too scared to appear because of the intense media interest.  But she backed the decisions taken by junior staff who found insufficient evidence to back up Ms Fitzpatrick’s suspicions about the letters. However First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs she was “absolutely horrified” when shown the photo of Ms Fitzpatrick allegedly taped to a chair and gagged. She has ordered a top civil servant to conduct a full review into the circumstances and report to her personally. Ms Fitzpatrick’s sister-in-law Sherry said: “The Fitzpatrick family are hugely disappointed with the result of the tribunal.

title: jet lag tips combat tiredness
story: NewsJet lag tips to combat tiredness after long-haul travel revealedA poll of 2,000 adults who have experienced jet lag found more than eight in 10 have struggled with severe fatigue after a long-haul flightShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEmma Elsworthy16:01, 16 AUG 2018Updated16:03, 16 AUG 2018NewsStudies have shown cherries can help prevent jet lag because they are one of the only natural sources of melatonin - a hormone which helps regulate sleep patternsGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAvoiding alcohol, exercising on the plane and eating cherries have been named in a list of ways to combat jet lag, according to a new study. A poll of 2,000 adults who have experienced jet lag found more than eight in 10 have struggled with severe fatigue after a long-haul flight. Other methods employed include drinking lots of water, giving caffeine the heave-ho and sleeping on the plane as much as possible.  The study was conducted by Love Fresh Cherries , the industry body which supplies cherries to UK supermarkets - in association with NW Cherries .  Registered nutritionist, Anita Bean, said: “Jet lag occurs when your internal body clock becomes disrupted due to crossing time zones.  The main symptoms include fatigue, insomnia, digestive problems, appetite changes and concentration and memory problems. “There’s no cure for jet lag but there are steps you can take before, during and after the flight to help minimise the effects.” Other techniques to get body-clocks back on track include keeping watches set to the time back home and staying awake until pre-travel bedtime. It also emerged, 44 per cent have been unable to sleep the night after returning from a different time zone. On average it takes those polled more than three days to get back to equilibrium after flying long-haul. And it typically sets them back nine hours of sleep each time they suffer a case of dreaded jet lag.  Three in 10 Brits have struggled to concentrate when returning to work and a tenth have even suffered anxiety brought on by shifting time zones after travel. One in 10 have struggled with constipation and a third have suffered from a debilitating headache. A quarter of tired jet lag sufferers said the condition makes them feel frustrated and nearly four in 10 claimed it leaves them feeling totally unproductive. Nearly half admitted jet lag makes them more irritable and 20 per cent feel a general heightening of emotion - making them more prone to bursting into tears. A quarter of respondents have even fallen asleep somewhere unusual due to fatigue from jet lag. Three in 10 have nodded off at work, a fifth have felt their eyes droop while sitting on the loo and a quarter have even fallen asleep behind the wheel of their car.

title: level results more quarter grades
story: NewsA-Level results: More than a QUARTER of all grades A or A* - the highest proportion for six yearsHundreds of thousands of students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland are receiving their A-level results today following major exam reformsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByIan JonesAlison KershawSophie Evans09:30, 16 AUG 2018Updated10:27, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than one in four A-levels were awarded an A or A* this year - the highest proportion for six years, national figures show. In total, 26.4 per cent of UK entries were given one of the two top grades, according to data published by the Joint Council for Qualifications (JCQ). This is up 0.1 percentage points on last year. However, figures also show that the proportion of A-Levels handed the very top result has fallen to its lowest level since 2013. One in 12 (8.0%) entries scored an A* grade this year, down 0.3 percentage points on 2017, statistics published by the council show.  The overall A*-E pass rate has also fallen 0.3 percentage points to 97.6%. This is the lowest level since 2010.   A Level results day 2018: All you need to know when you get your grades and what to do next  But the percentage of A-Levels awarded an A or A* is the highest since 2012, according to a Press Association analysis. It is the second year in a row that the A*-A pass rate has risen. Boys continue to outperform girls at the highest grades, the figures show. While 26.6% of boys' entries were awarded at least an A grade this year, this was the case for 26.2% of girls' entries. The statistics also show that STEM subjects (science, technology, engineering and maths) are continuing to rise in popularity. More than a third (36.2%) of all A-level entries were in these subjects, up from 34.5% last year, and 28% in 2009.  Male students are still more likely to study a STEM subject than females, but the balance is shifting, JCQ said. More girls take biology and chemistry than boys, while more boys take maths and physics. But the data also shows that girls are closing in on the boys, with a 3.1% increase in maths entries from female students (boys' entries for the subject have risen 2.1%) and a 6.9% rise in physics (2.4% for boys). More than half a million students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland are finding out their A-Level results today after an anxious wait. It comes in the wake of a major exams overhaul - with 24 A-level subjects now reformed. There has been a move away from coursework and modular exams, with sixth-formers instead sitting their exams at the end of two years of study. There have been major reforms to A-Level qualifications in England - with a move away from coursework and modular exams.  Instead, sixth formers sit their exams at the end of two years of study. A Department for Education spokeswoman said: We reformed A-levels after universities told us they were failing to prepare students for higher education. Reducing the number of exams students have to sit will give them more time for study and to gain a deeper understanding of the courses they are studying, an essential skill for undergraduate study. We know exam season can be a time of heightened emotions for pupils wanting to do their best but while testing has always been an important part of education, it should never be at the expense of a young person's wellbeing. That's why the Government is investing &pound1.7 billion to promote, protect and improve young people's mental health. Grades have been awarded for the first time this summer for new A-levels in languages, geography, dance, drama and theatre, music, PE and religious studies. They join the 13 A-level subjects for which the first grades were handed out last summer. Maths is in the process of being reformed and a small number of grades were handed out for the new qualification this summer. Most students have been awarded grades after studying the old A-level course. Overall, the subject is still the most popular A-level, with 2,383 more entries this year compared to 2017. Michael Turner, JCQ director general, said: Students, and teachers, should be congratulated. They can be confident in their grades, knowing they have been achieved in a world-class system that is robust, challenging and fair.  It comes as early figures have showed there has been a fall in the number of students accepted on degree courses at UK universities. In total, 411,860 students - from the UK and overseas - have taken up places, according to initial data published by admissions service Ucas. This is down 1% compared with the same point last year A breakdown shows 353,960 UK students have been accepted on to undergraduate courses, down 2% on 2017. But there is an increase in international students, with 26,400 EU applicants accepted to study at UK universities - up 1% on last year. And a record 31,510 students from nations outside the EU have taken up places - a 4% increase. The figures are a snapshot taken by Ucas shortly after midnight.    The admissions service said that in England, a record 27.9% of the 18-year-old population has been accepted on to courses, with a record 26.3% in Wales. In Northern Ireland, the entry rate is 28.1%, while in Scotland - where results were published last week - 25.9% of 18-year-olds have been accepted. Clare Marchant, Ucas chief executive, said an increase in the proportion of youngsters from disadvantaged background was excellent news. Some 16.1% of those from the most disadvantaged backgrounds have been accepted - up 0.4 percentage points. She added: However, the continuing gap between the most and least advantaged is frustrating, and we'll keep on working with universities to help them evaluate their outreach activities to impact the most disadvantaged students. The encouraging growth in international students choosing to study in the UK is testament to the welcome of our world-class universities. Students need to get around 55% of the answers right in their Biology A-level in order to secure an A grade, grade boundaries for one exam board suggest. The A grade pass mark required for the reformed OCR advanced Biology A-level is 54.8%, the figures on its website show. Those wanting an A in the reformed maths exam would need to get 65.6% of the answers right. Meanwhile, students who sat the English language A-level would be looking for 77% of the marks in order to secure an A. I'd advise anyone thinking about securing a place through clearing to take some time to visit universities and colleges in the next few days. This weekend's open days are listed on the Ucas website. Seeing everything in person can help you make the right decision. If you decide your next step isn't a degree though, information on apprenticeships, gap years and career options is also available on ucas. While many students hoping to go to a university or college of their choice will get the grades they need today, others will inevitably be left disappointed. But The Grand Tour presenter Jeremy Clarkson has told them not to worry. He tweeted: Don’t worry if your A level grades aren’t any good. I got a C and 2 Us. And I’m sitting here deciding which of my Range Rovers to use today. Earlier, Amanda Brown, deputy general secretary of the National Education Union, had argued that changes to A-Levels means that students are unable to fully demonstrate what they can do. Hundreds of thousands of teenagers have received their A-Levels today. Below, you can see the pass rate (students receiving A-E grades), broken down by nation and by region. (The figure in brackets is the change in percentage points on 2017) Nation England 97.6% (down 0.3) Wales 97.4% (down 0.3) Northern Ireland 98.2% (down 0.1) Region North-east England 98.2% (no change) North-west England 98.0% (down 0.2) Yorkshire &amp Humber 97.7% (down 0.2) West Midlands 96.9% (down 0.5) East Midlands 97.6% (down 0.1) Eastern England 97.8% (down 0.1) South-west England 97.8% (down 0.1) South-east England 97.9% (down 0.1) London 97.0% (down 0.6) All 97.6% (down 0.3) Here are the rates for students receiving the top grades (A and A*)... England 26.2% (no change) Wales 26.3% (up 1.3) Northern Ireland 30.4% (no change) North-east England 22.8% (down 0.5) North-west England 24.6% (up 0.1) Yorkshire &amp Humber 24.4% (up 0.9) West Midlands 22.6% (down 0.4) East Midlands 23.1% (down 0.2) Eastern England 26.4% (down 0.4) South-west England 26.8% (up 0.1) South-east England 29.3% (up 0.4) London 28.1% (down 0.6) All 26.4% (up 0.1) Changing the assessment of A-levels so they focus on high-stakes exams taken at the end of two years of study does not allow students to properly demonstrate their ability and puts them under huge pressure, she said. Coursework and other non-exam assessments are a better way for students to demonstrate their skills, are less of a memory test, and help lower attaining students and those with special educational needs and disabilities show their achievements. But Education Secretary Damian Hinds said the redesign of the qualifications would make them more appropriate, better (at) preparing young people for moving on to the next stage, including university. He told Today: Having exams at the end of the two years means that it is possible to consider the subject as a whole, to bring in all the different parts of it, to synthesise the different aspects of the subject in a way that is a little closer to undergraduate study.  A Department for Education spokeswoman said: We reformed A-levels after universities told us they were failing to prepare students for higher education. Reducing the number of exams students have to sit will give them more time for study and to gain a deeper understanding of the courses they are studying, an essential skill for undergraduate study. We know exam season can be a time of heightened emotions for pupils wanting to do their best but while testing has always been an important part of education, it should never be at the expense of a young person's wellbeing. That's why the Government is investing &pound1.7 billion to promote, protect and improve young people's mental health. You can find out all you need to know about getting your grades here Key statistics in this year's A-Level results Here are the main figures in this year's A-level results: - The proportion of A-Levels receiving top grades is the highest since 2012. A total of 26.4% entrants scored either an A or A*, up slightly on 26.3% in 2017. - 8.0% of entrants received an A, down from 8.3% last year. This is the lowest level since 2013, when it was 7.6%.  - The overall pass rate (grades A-E) was 97.6%, down from 97.9% last year. This is the lowest pass rate since 2010, when it was also 97.6%. - Boys lead girls in the top grades for the second year running. The proportion of boys who got A or higher was 26.6%, 0.4 percentage points higher than girls (26.2%). - Last year, boys led girls by 0.5 percentage points (26.6% boys, 26.1% girls). Before 2017, girls had traditionally led boys, though the gap had been narrowing since 2008. - The gap between the best-performing boys and girls has fallen slightly. The proportion of boys who got A was 8.5%, 0.9 percentage points higher than girls (7.6%). - In 2017 the figures were 8.8% for boys, 7.8% girls - a gap of 1.0 points.
